Article Title: CORRUPTION IN VISEGRAD FOUR COUNTRIES
Source Title: 7TH INTERNATIONAL DAYS OF STATISTICS AND ECONOMICS
Conference Title: 7th International Days of Statistics and Economics
Conference Sponsor: Univ Econ, Dept Stat & Probabil,Univ Econ, Dept Microeconom,Univ Econ, Fac Business Econ,Ceska Sporitelna,ESC Rennes Int Sch Business
Author Keywords: Corruption Perception Index; Global Competitiveness Index
Abstract: Corruption as an economic phenomena is mentioned in the first part of paper. Differences in the extent of corruption among countries can be explained by the summary of the main causes and consequences of corruption. Corruption influences economic performance and competitiveness. The level of corruption in post communist countries is above EU average level and it is usually higher in the former communist countries than in most European Union countries. The second part of paper will focus on the level of corruption in the Czech Republic, Slovak Republic, Hungary, Poland and Austria. The Visegrad Four countries have gone through similar social and historical development in recent decades. Comparison of the four countries has confirmed the hypothesis that the level of corruption is influenced by social developments and traditions. Austria is mentioned as an example of a country that went through the centuries similar development such as Visegrad Four countries but its situation was different during the communist regime in the other mentioned countries. If development is comparable in the Visegrad Four countries and different from the situation in Austria it can be interpreted as a consequence of the communist regime.

Article Title: The Romanian Agriculture - Source of Competitive Advantage
Source Title: CREATING GLOBAL COMPETITIVE ECONOMIES: 2020 VISION PLANNING & IMPLEMENTATION, VOLS 1-3
Conference Title: 22nd International-Business-Information-Management-Association Conference on Creating Global Competitive Economies: 2020 Vision Planning and Implementation
Conference Sponsor: Int Business Informat Management Assoc
Author Keywords: agriculture; competitive advantage; resource
Abstract: The work includes a macroeconomic analysis of the primary sector, the agriculture of Romania in the european context. The goal is to identify which are the agricultural resources that represent a real competitive advantage. There were analyzed the following resources: natural resources (climate, land fluid etc.), capital resources, labor resources, technical resources, organizational resources and market resources. Resource evaluation was performed through synthetic indicators, namely: used agricultural area per capita, used agricultural area per farm, climate incertitude, financial capital per hectare, agricultural area per agricultural equipment, labor consumption per hectare, intensification factors consumption per hectare, the typology of farms and trade balance. The indicators value places the Romanian agriculture on the first 5-7 place in terms of natural resources and in the bottom of the leaderboard for the other resource types. Results that the main source of competitive advantage of Romanian agriculture is represented by the natural resources and in part on the type of farm.

Article Title: ANTI-CORRUPTION POLICY IN THE CZECH REPUBLIC
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 10TH INTERNATIONAL SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCE: ECONOMIC POLICY IN THE EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER COUNTRIES: SELECTED PAPERS
Conference Title: 10th International Scientific Conference on Economic Policy in the European Union Member Countries

Author Keywords: corruption; anti-corruption policy; Czech Republic; economic policy; ethics; economic ethics; economic transformation
Abstract: The Czech Republic was attempted bribery of public entities qualify as a crime deserving the most severe sentences already in the Premyslovci. Remarkable, however, that despite this fact, the corruption in the Czech Republic always well managed. This paradox is, to some extent the result of the fact that the Czech Republic remain high long-term effectiveness of corrupt activity is the gain from corruption highly outweigh its risks. While the requirement of reliability as a key principle of successful operation of businesses and public administration in particular, was implemented into the legal form was during the First Republic. The present article deals with the anti-corruption policy in the Czech Republic, analyzed is the past twenty years, when building an effective anti-corruption policy in the Czech Republic is an integral component of wider processes of democratization of Czech society.

Article Title: Effect of crop selection on the economy of crop production and quality of the environment
Source Title: AGRARIAN PERSPECTIVES XXII: DEVELOPMENT TRENDS IN AGRIBUSINESS
Conference Title: 22nd International Scientific Conference on Agrarian Perspectives - Development Trends in Agribusiness
Conference Sponsor: Czech Univ Life Sci Prague, Fac Econ & Management
Author Keywords: crop production; yield; costs; nitrate; production function; winter wheat
Keywords Plus: FIELD CROPS
Abstract: This paper describes approaches to evaluation of production according to production focus. For this purpose, appropriate assembly plants in given soil and climatic conditions, especially from an agronomic point of view and from the point of view of environmental protection are used. The achievable profit in terms of specific production focus differs by up to CZK 1,500 per hectare. The work includes analysis of agricultural land revenues in terms of the focus on the production of cereals, oilseeds and livestock. It analyzes value of returns on agricultural land using BPEJ. Main basis is certified methodology of calculation of the gross annual rent effect, for specific values of inputs of nutrients, plant protection products and technology costs. The model adjusts returns and costs of agricultural crops according to the current price and cost developments. The paper also evaluates the loss of gross annual rent effect due to incorrect sequencing of crops,\ especially on the basis of reduced revenues. Observed decline in gross annual rent effect due to improper crop rotation sequence may be up to 1900 CZK per hectare. With respect to the protection of the environment functions for nitrogen doses 50, 90, 100, 110 % are evaluated for given soil and climatic conditions. The impact of 50 % dose reduction of nitrogen is in the case of winter wheat on average 600 CZK per hectare. Own choice of production structure affects economic results especially in warmer climatic regions and while intensive production is used.

Article Title: The Possible Use of Alternative Methods of Measuring GDP in Forming of Economic Policy of Slovakia
Source Title: CREATING GLOBAL COMPETITIVE ECONOMIES: 2020 VISION PLANNING & IMPLEMENTATION, VOLS 1-3
Conference Title: 22nd International-Business-Information-Management-Association Conference on Creating Global Competitive Economies: 2020 Vision Planning and Implementation
Conference Sponsor: Int Business Informat Management Assoc
Author Keywords: Economic policy; Alternative Measurements; Better Life Index
Abstract: Quantitative dimension of economic growth as measured by GDP per capita is necessary, but not sufficient to measure the qualitative development of the society. Statisticians and economists recognize the need to provide policy makers and civil society, reliable, timely and credible indicator that can quantitatively and qualitatively assess the current situation, which would also indicate prospects for further economic growth. These limits constrain many economists and the various groups to address the need to actively explore alternative methods which would take into account the qualitative aspects of growth and contribute to the elimination of these deficiencies in the measurements.

Article Title: ECONOMIC COHESION OF POLISH AND EUROPEAN UNION REGIONS
Source Title: 7TH INTERNATIONAL DAYS OF STATISTICS AND ECONOMICS
Conference Title: 7th International Days of Statistics and Economics
Conference Sponsor: Univ Econ, Dept Stat & Probabil,Univ Econ, Dept Microeconom,Univ Econ, Fac Business Econ,Ceska Sporitelna,ESC Rennes Int Sch Business
Author Keywords: economic cohesion; sigma and beta convergence; Markov chain
Keywords Plus: CONVERGENCE
Abstract: In recent years we can observe a growing interest in the problem of cohesion because of its crucial role in sustainable development. Economic cohesion is usually considered at the macroeconomic level, but it should be noted, that it is possible the situation in which the development gaps between countries will be reduced but at the level of regions the differences will increase. Objective of the study is to assess the economic cohesion of Polish regions and cohesion of Member States of the European Union. In the analysis are used the GDP per capita in terms of GDP per capita in Poland and in the European Union. The study allows to verify the hypothesis that the convergence processes between Polish regions and countries of the European Union occur. Sigma and beta convergence methods and Markov chains are applied in the evaluation of the economic cohesion. The research is based on the data from Central Statistical Office in Poland and data from Eurostat in the years 2000-2009.

Article Title: Analysis of Rural Credit Union Problem of Shandong province
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE THIRD SYMPOSIUM OF RISK ANALYSIS AND RISK MANAGEMENT IN WESTERN CHINA
Conference Title: 3rd Symposium of Risk Analysis and Risk Management in Western China
Conference Location: Guizhou Univ Finance & Econ, Sch Finance, Guiyang, PEOPLES R CHINA

Conference Host: Guizhou Univ Finance & Econ, Sch Finance
Author Keywords: Micro-credit; Shandong rural credit cooperative; Lack of credit
Abstract: Shandong rural credit cooperative is a major institution offering rural financial service in Shandong province. The introduction of micro-credit loans for farmers to meet their financial needs, to some extent, makes up for the inadequate supply of Shandong rural financial status. The micro-credit of Shandong rural cooperative, featured with no collateral, mainly focuses on business loans of individuals or families. Meanwhile, although there are some problems and risks, the development of micro-credit supports the local agricultural economy.

Article Title: Geological Relics Tourism Resources Protection and Scientific Management-Taking Zhangye Danxia and Colored Hills Landform of Gansu Province as an Example
Source Title: INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON COMPLEX SCIENCE MANAGEMENT AND EDUCATION SCIENCE (CSMES 2013)
Conference Title: International Conference on Complex Science Management and Education Science (CSMES)
Conference Sponsor: Adv Sci Res Ctr
Author Keywords: scientific management; geological relic resources; Danxia and Coloured Hilly Landscape
Abstract: With the improvement of China national geological park construction system in recent years, geological tourism becomes an important part of tourism development strategy. Geological tourism depends on geological relics tourism resources, and geological relic tourism resource refers to the geological tourism resources with high value of research, education. Among emerging tourism resources protection work, the geological relics tourism resources generate its special protection and scientific management system. Based on taking Danxia Color Hilly Landform of Zhangye of Gansu Province as an example, this paper analyzes the macroscopic situation and scientific significance of geological relics tourism resources of the scenic spot, and puts forward some countermeasures of geological relics tourism resources protection and scientific management for Zhangye Danxia National Geological Park in Gansu Province and other domestic geological parks, and provides reference for geological relics resources protection and scientific management.

Article Title: The Empirical Research on the Relationship Between Patent Output and Region Economic Growth: Based on the data of Sichuan Province
Source Title: GMC 13: PROCEEDINGS OF THE NINTH INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON GLOBAL MANUFACTURING AND CHINA
Conference Title: 9th International Symposium on Global Manufacturing and China (GMC '13)
Conference Sponsor: Zhejiang Univ,Univ Cambridge,Univ Cambridge, Inst Mfg,Zhejiang Univ, Natl Inst Innovat,Zhejiang Univ, Univ Cambridge, Joint Res Ctr Global Mfg & Innovat Management
Author Keywords: patent output; co-integration theory; error correction model; Granger Causality test
Abstract: Patent output is an important measure of local innovative competitiveness, and also is an indicator of local comprehensive competitiveness. In this paper, we collect the data of patents output and GDP of Sichuan province, and carry out stationary test using the co-integration theory. As the conclusion we found there is a long-term dynamic equilibrium relationship between Sichuan's patent output and economic growth. In order to give full play to the patent technology in the role of economic growth, Sichuan province should attach importance to the patent management, especially pay more attention to patent transformation of achievements.

Article Title: Study on the Construction and Operation of Student Work Pattern with Specialized Characteristics-A Case Study Based on CWNU
Source Title: INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON COMPLEX SCIENCE MANAGEMENT AND EDUCATION SCIENCE (CSMES 2013)
Conference Title: International Conference on Complex Science Management and Education Science (CSMES)
Conference Sponsor: Adv Sci Res Ctr
Author Keywords: student work pattern; specialized characteristics; construction; operation
Abstract: Student work is an important task in colleges and universities, which plays a more and more vital role in harmonious campus construction and students' comprehensive development cultivation. However, the conventional student work pattern can't meet the requirements of the popularization of higher education, which requires the cultivation of builders and successors with free and harmonious development in an all-around way. Therefore, we should stick to the new way of thinking, planning and conducting student work according to the characteristics of each specialty. In the years of practice in college students' education and management, CWNU (short for China West Normal University) has explored a three-dimensional student work pattern characterized by specialized features. With its own theoretical basis, connotation and characteristics, these patterns constantly enriches and perfects itself in the process of practice. The student work pattern in colleges and universities has been proceeding in tune with the economic and social conditions and the advancement of higher education in China. Such progress has revealed both the functional orientation and the purpose of student work in higher education at different periods, and presented the external form and the intrinsic value appeal of the student work. As an integral part of higher education, the core and aim of student work is to educate students, and promote the students' integrated development as well. CWNU, laying emphasis on the combination of activities with specialized features and students' development in an all-round way in years of practice in students educating, has explored the student work pattern with specialized features.

Authors: Zhang, Y; Zhang, JY; Zheng, YL
Author Full Names: Zhang Ying; Zhang Jingyuan; Zheng Yunlin
Article Title: Study of the Influence of Reporting Format on Commercial Banks
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 5TH (2013) INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON FINANCIAL RISK AND CORPORATE FINANCE MANAGEMENT, VOLS I AND II
Conference Title: 5th International Conference on Financial Risk and Corporate Finance Management
Conference Sponsor: Dalian Univ Technol, Fac Management & Econom
Author Keywords: commercial banks; reporting format; accounting treatments
Keywords Plus: DISCLOSURE
Abstract: The difference of accounting treatments dealing with the fair-value gains or losses between US Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) and International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) raises questions because they are either recognized or disclosed in the financial reporting. By reporting provisions on financial instruments and derivatives, analyses the empirical evidence of differences between recognition and disclosure, this article shows that investors and analysts'valuation of banks have been strongly influenced by the accounting measures, which will produce unfair comparisons within the industry and mislead investors. Through discussing the implication to financial reporting standard setters, the authors conclude that the accounting standard setters should establish a uniform rule to recognize the fair-value gains and/or losses and bring the off-balance sheet trading back to on-balance sheet.

Article Title: The Analysis of Coping with Low-carbon Barriers on China's Textile and Clothing Trade with Game Theory
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 5TH (2013) INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON FINANCIAL RISK AND CORPORATE FINANCE MANAGEMENT, VOLS I AND II
Conference Title: 5th International Conference on Financial Risk and Corporate Finance Management
Conference Sponsor: Dalian Univ Technol, Fac Management & Econom
Author Keywords: textile and clothing trade; low-carbon barriers; game theory
Abstract: Under the guidance of low carbon economy, low-carbon barriers form and will become the main barrier in international trade. Textile and clothing industry has long played the role of big polluters. The rise and development of low-carbon barriers will certainly have enormous influence on the textile and clothing trade. This paper takes a further research on how to cope with low-carbon barriers with game theory, in order to realize the transformation from big textile country to strong textile country.

Authors: Zhu, C; Li, QX; Liao, SS
Author Full Names: Zhu, Chen; Li, Qixing; Liao, Stephen Shaoyi
Article Title: Business Network-Based Framework Design for Financial Fraud Detection
Source Title: VISION 2020: INNOVATION, DEVELOPMENT SUSTAINABILITY, AND ECONOMIC GROWTH, VOLS 1-3
Conference Title: 21st International-Business-Information-Management-Association Conference on Vision 2020: Innovation, Development Sustainability, and Economic Growth
Conference Sponsor: Vienna Univ Technol,Int Business Informat Management Assoc
Author Keywords: Financial fraud detection; context feature construction; business network; design science; social cognitive theory
Keywords Plus: BEHAVIOR
Abstract: Since investors, financial professionals, and the securities and exchange administrators highly rely on the financial filings for information about companies they are evaluating for investment purposes, it is impractical to solely trust a financial institute's assessment report or manual approach to identify financial fraud given that there are increasing numbers of companies listed or looking for investment every day. The research and development of automated financial fraud detection system are of great challenge because of the fact that there is a separation between the normal deception detection techniques and the financial statements analysis. Guided by design science research methodology, we propose an analytical framework to detect financial fraud of companies based on an extended social cognitive theory. Business network analysis is introduced as a novel approach to derive latent contextual features. The potential performance of the prototype system will contribute to implementation into both theoretical and practical domains.

Authors: Botshekan, M; Kraeussl, R; Lucas, A
Author Full Names: Botshekan, Mahmoud; Kraeussl, Roman; Lucas, Andre
Article Title: Cash Flow and Discount Rate Risk in Up and Down Markets: What Is Actually Priced?
Source Title: JOURNAL OF FINANCIAL AND QUANTITATIVE ANALYSIS
Keywords Plus: CROSS-SECTION; RETURN; EQUILIBRIUM; VARIANCE; SKEWNESS
Abstract: We test whether asymmetric preferences for losses versus gains affect the prices of cash flow versus discount rate risk. We construct a return decomposition distinguishing cash flow and discount rate betas in up and down markets. Using U.S. data, we find that downside cash flow and discount rate betas carry the largest premia. Downside cash flow risk is priced consistently across different samples, periods, and return decomposition methods. It is the only component of beta with significant out-of-sample predictive ability. Downside cash flow premia mainly occur for small stocks, while large stocks are compensated for symmetric cash-flow-related risk.

Authors: Cartea, A; Saúl, J; Toro, J
Author Full Names: Cartea, Alvaro; Saul, Jonatan; Toro, Juan
Article Title: Optimal portfolio choice in real terms: Measuring the benefits of TIPS
Author Keywords: Portfolio choice in real terms; Treasury Inflation Indexed Securities (TIPS); Buy-and-hold long-term investors; Money illusion
Keywords Plus: ASSET ALLOCATION; RISKY ASSETS; INFLATION; RETURNS; MARKET; BONDS; RATES
Abstract: In this paper we solve an optimal portfolio choice problem to measure the benefits of Treasury Inflation Indexed Securities (TIPS) to investors concerned with maximizing real wealth. We show how the introduction of a real riskless asset completes the investor asset space, by contrasting optimal portfolio allocations with and without such assets. We use historical data to quantify gains from availability of TIPS in the presence of other asset classes such as equities, commodities, and real estate. We draw a distinction between buy-and-hold long-term investors for whom TIPS fully displace nominal risk-free assets and short-term investors for whom TIPS improve the investment opportunity set of real returns. Finally, we show how gains from TIPS are tempered by the availability of alternative assets that covary with inflation, such as gold and real estate. (C) 2012 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Article Title: The effect of anger and anxiety traits on investment decisions
Author Keywords: Anger; Anxiety; Personality traits; Economic decision-making; Personal finance
Keywords Plus: RISK-TAKING; PERSONALITY; JUDGMENTS; APPRAISAL; FEELINGS; EMOTION; REASON
Abstract: This study investigates the extent to which people make financial decisions on the basis of their dispositional tendency to engage in a specific emotion, such as anger or anxiety. We predicted that trait anger is associated with the decision to invest, whereas trait anxiety motivates individuals to avoid investments. We employed a six question survey, considering real life investment decisions, stock trend predictability and preference toward risk investments, and three hypothetic scenarios to measure the participants' risk attitudes in the area of finance. The results showed that trait anger predicted risky decisions: it was positively associated with the willingness to invest money in different kinds of stocks, preferring medium/long-term investments, and with high predictability assessment in the forecast of stock trends. Contrarily, trait anxiety predicted conservative financial decisions: it was associated with the decision not to invest savings, to hold interest-bearing accounts, and with low predictability of stock trends. In hypothetic scenarios trait anger predicted a medium risk portfolio and the decision to wait before selling both loss and gain investments, while trait anxiety was associated with the preference for a low risk portfolio and with the decision to immediately sell a stock both if it increases or decreases in value. These data are consistent with cognitive models of emotions, highlighting their functional utility and extend the knowledge of the relationship between personality traits and real life investment decision-making. (C) 2012 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: McShane, MK; Cox, LA; Ge, YL
Author Full Names: McShane, Michael K.; Cox, Larry A.; Ge, Yanling
Article Title: Early Mover Advantages: Evidence From the Long-Term Care Insurance Market
Keywords Plus: FINANCIAL INNOVATIONS; FIRM SURVIVAL; AGENCY COSTS; EVOLUTION; BEHAVIOR
Abstract: Researchers frequently question whether financial firms benefit by developing new products because barriers to entry common to other industries generally do not exist. Studies of early mover advantages for new financial products provide mixed evidence at best. We find evidence of early mover advantages in the relatively young market for long-term care insurance (LTCI) using data that allow broad testing of financial performance. Product differentiation, individual lines exposure, firm size, and traditional health insurance experience also affect financial performance.

Article Title: Globalization and gender equality in the course of development
Author Keywords: Globalization; Gender equality; Social institutions; Female subjugation
Keywords Plus: ECONOMIC-GROWTH; INEQUALITY; EDUCATION; EMPLOYMENT; DEMOCRACY; INDEX; CIVIL; SET
Abstract: We empirically assess the influence of globalization on social institutions that govern female subjugation and gender equality in developing countries. Observing the progress of globalization for almost one hundred developing countries at ten year intervals starting in 1970, we find that economic and social globalization exert a decidedly positive influence on the social institutions that reduce female subjugation and promote gender equality. Authors: Doherty, NA; Kartasheva, AV; Phillips, RD
Author Full Names: Doherty, Neil A.; Kartasheva, Anastasia V.; Phillips, Richard D.
Article Title: Information effect of entry into credit ratings market: The case of insurers' ratings
Author Keywords: Ratings; Competition; Information disclosure; Insurance
Keywords Plus: FINANCIAL STRENGTH RATINGS; INSURANCE MARKETS; SELECTION BIAS; QUALITY; CERTIFICATION; COMPETITION; REPUTATION; BANKRUPTCY; DISCLOSURE; MECHANISM
Abstract: The paper analyzes the effect of competition between credit rating agencies (CRAs) on the information content of ratings. We show that a monopolistic CRA pools sellers into multiple rating classes and has partial market coverage. This provides an opportunity for market entry. The entrant designs a rating scale distinct from that of the incumbent. It targets higher-than-average companies in each rating grade of the incumbent's rating scale and employs more stringent rating standards. We use Standard and Poor's (S&P) entry into the market for insurance ratings previously covered by a monopolist, A.M. Best, to empirically test the impact of entry on the information content of ratings. The empirical analysis reveals that S&P required higher standards to assign a rating similar to the one assigned by A.M. Best and that higher-than-average quality insurers in each rating category of AM. Best chose to receive a second rating from S&P. (C) 2012 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
